title: help the hungry coronavirus food bank felix project covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The Independent is calling for support to get food to the most vulnerable during the coronavirus crisis – and you can helpThe Independent has&nbsplaunched&nbspan appeal to help those going hungry because of the coronavirus crisis.From parents struggling to feed their families after losing their jobs to the vulnerable who have been told to stay inside for the good of their health, thousands across the country now need our help – while many who already used food banks are relying on them more than ever.Across Britain, community hubs are being set up in response to the outbreak to deliver food to many of these people. We have teamed up with The Felix Project – a start-up charity we helped launch in 2016 – to deliver produce to community hubs in London boroughs.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Independent is also asking food charities across Britain to contact helpthehungry@ to tell us about your project and help build a directory of ways that our readers can help the hungry in their area – through money, volunteering and food donations. Food banks, which were already struggling to meet the need for emergency food parcels, have seen a huge surge in demand in recent weeks, while at the same time coping with dwindling donations, supermarket rationing systems, and a loss of many volunteers to self-isolation – yet none of the government’s rescue money goes to them.British households have stored more than £1bn worth of goods in their homes in response to the pandemic, creating shortages for food banks as shoppers ignore assurances that supply chains are robust.How to support our campaignJess Phillips, the Labour MP who recently ran for party leader, has backed our campaign, saying: “Nobody should be in the position of not being able to get enough food. In my constituency, London and in places all around the UK the coronavirus pandemic is placing extra stress on a system that was already straining.“We should all do what we can to help food and other essentials get to those that need it. That is why I’m backing the Help the Hungry campaign – please give if you are able.”Pastor Obi Onyeabor, the manager at Barking Foodbank, part of The Trussell Trust’s national network, said his pool of around 50 volunteers has been reduced by a dozen or so people currently self-isolating at home. Yet he and his team have kept their two church hall food banks open, and are now making home deliveries on Tuesdays and Thursdays to make sure the most vulnerable get supplies.“We have been scrambling for the past couple of weeks, doing all that we can – but we’re appealing for more people to come and help,” he said. “Out of fear people have been buying for themselves and their families, but I’ve seen some real generosity too.“I hope that if we can get past the panic buying stage, more people will want to give money, food or some of their time too.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailIn London, charities like The Felix Project donate 10 tons of food – or 22,000 meals – to the needy every day. But funding has dropped since the outbreak of Covid-19, limiting their capacity to carry out vital work at a time when it is more important than ever. As part of the London Food Alliance, along with FareShare and City Harvest, The Felix Project will coordinate deliveries in London boroughs in order to distribute surplus food to the elderly, poor and vulnerable. The charities will deliver food to the hubs, where local volunteers will package up parcels and arrange “last-mile” deliveries to the homes of the vulnerable.Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, has backed our campaign to help in the capital in partnership with our sister title the Evening Standard. He said: “In a city as prosperous as London, everyone should have enough food to feed themselves and their families – but unfortunately the coronavirus outbreak means some Londoners are facing even greater difficulties. It’s commendable these organisations are joining forces to help ensure surplus food isn’t wasted and instead reaches those who need it most. I urge Londoners to support this crucial initiative.”Mark Curtin, CEO of The Felix Project, said: “Our role is to pick up large volumes of nutritious surplus food from the commercial sector and deliver it to community hubs to ensure there is enough food for vulnerable people for as long as this health crisis ensues. We will be working all hours doing our bit – and it would be wonderful if your readers can get behind us so we can do this job for London.”Emma Revie, chief executive of The Trussell Trust, which supports 1,200 food banks, appealed for help from the public to get vital food to people who cannot afford the basics, and to boost volunteer numbers in areas where they are needed.“Our main priority as coronavirus unfolds is ensuring the safety of everyone who comes to a food bank – whether it’s someone needing help, someone volunteering their time, or someone making a donation,” said Ms Revie. “Until we are confident that adequate government protection against poverty is in place, food banks provide an essential community service to people unable to afford food. But this should not fall to food banks.“Our benefits system could be the life raft people need now. That’s why it’s more important than ever that we end the five-week wait for universal credit. While incredible food bank volunteers continue to help people unable to afford the basics, we would ask our government to take this essential step and end the five-week wait now. It’s five weeks too long.”Sabine Goodwin, coordinator of the Independent Food Aid Network UK, which oversees 834 independent food banks, said the charitable services were “struggling to stay above water” in the current climate and accused the government of so far “failing to act” to prevent an ever-increasing number of people falling into poverty.“Food bank use was rising before the coronavirus outbreak and the impact of job losses can only make matters far worse. But this catastrophe in the making is avoidable,” she said. “We’re calling for an income-based solution to this crisis which would mean that the Herculean efforts by volunteers across the country wouldn’t be needed.“FareShare, the UK’s biggest food redistribution charity, is also calling for more volunteers to help with packing and making van deliveries. The organisation takes food from the food manufacturers that can’t be sold in shops, either because of packaging errors or overproduction, and gets it out to food banks, hospices, homeless hostels and other charities.Commercial director Alyson Walsh estimates around 1,200 people have got in touch over the past week. “We have quite a lot of older volunteers who have had to stay at home, but we are now seeing a wave of interest in new people willing to fill in.”Ms Walsh added: “We know we have the capacity to do more – we have the warehouse&nbspspace and the chillers. But the government needs to help the food industry do more in terms of all the bagging and boxing and delivery of food that needs to be done.”Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: help the hungry food banks meals london felix project lockdown
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘We feel as though we’re making a small difference twice over’, says Oso Foundation trustee Karen Jenkel&nbspThe Felix Project, our Help The Hungry appeal partner in London, has quadrupled its supply of food to vulnerable Londoners to 42 tonnes – the equivalent of 100,000 meals a day. In the four weeks since lockdown, they have delivered 565 tonnes – a staggering 1.35 million meals.This extraordinary humanitarian effort – carried out with 22 delivery vans manned by a small army of volunteers – comes in the wake of rising food poverty and worrying new research on unemployment. &nbspThe Institute for Social and Economic Research at the University of Essex estimated at the weekend that at least 6.5 million jobs could be lost, a fifth of the national total, with the duration of the lockdown being critical as to whether job losses will be short-lived.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIt comes on top of a YouGov poll for The Food Foundation revealing that 8 million people in Britain face food insecurity and that 3&nbspmillion have already experienced hunger.As Felix scrambles to respond to the deepening distress with no government support, donations to our campaign, in conjunction with sister title the Evening Standard, are crucial to fund their fast-expanding operation.Today we can report a hugely generous donation from the Garfield Weston Foundation, who agreed to an emergency grant of £500,000 to be shared equally between The Felix Project and FareShare, London’s two biggest food surplus distributors, for their work supporting the most vulnerable families in the wake of the coronavirus.Our campaign raises over £1.5m for the vulnerablePhilippa Charles, director of the Garfield Weston Foundation, said: “Alongside significant grants to the National Emergency Trust among others, our trustees are keen to ensure that those most vulnerable and affected by this crisis receive the immediate support they need. We are delighted to support this partnership between two effective charities with which we have had long-standing relationships.”&nbspAnother donor to our appeal, which is approaching £2m, was the Oso Foundation, whose trustee Karen Jankel, said: “Doing the weekly grocery shop may have its challenges for most of us, but at least we can afford to put food on the table. The ethos behind The Felix Project appeals to us as we hate the idea of waste and so by giving them our donation, we feel as though we’re making a small difference twice over.”On Friday, Felix delivered 16 truckloads of nutritious food to community hubs in eight boroughs –​ Barnet, Enfield, Haringey, Harrow, Havering, Islington, Tower Hamlets and Waltham Forest – and a further 26 truckloads to 75 charities, schools and holiday clubs. All in all, this is the daily equivalent tonnage of three-and-a-half double-decker Routemaster buses.With more borough hubs set to come on stream in the coming days, demand for their services is set to rise yet further.The Independent is encouraging readers to help groups that are trying to feed the hungry across the country – find out how you can help here.&nbspFollow this link&nbspto donate to our campaign in London, in partnership with the Evening Standard.Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: meghan markle help the hungry campaign food bank donation coronavirus
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Duchess is long-running supporter of&nbspHubb community kitchen which is now helping to&nbspprovide&nbspmeals in response to epidemicThe Duchess of Sussex today backed The Independent’s “moving” appeal to raise funds for the delivery of food to poor, elderly and vulnerable Londoners during the coronavirus epidemic.Meghan’s support for our Help The Hungry appeal, in conjunction with the&nbspEvening Standard, came as the community kitchen close to Grenfell Tower that she supports unveiled a new meals delivery service for families struggling to feed themselves during the lockdown. The initiative will be launched on Monday when the Hubb Community Kitchen plans to start cooking between 250 and 300 meals a day, three days a week.&nbspThe scheme&nbspfollows a Zoom conference call last week, when the duchess talked to women involved in running the kitchen about how they could adapt their service to feed people at a time when social-distancing rules prevent it from opening as normal. Much of the produce will be supplied by The Independent’s charity partner The Felix Project which sources surplus food from cafes, restaurants and supermarkets.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMeghan said: “The spirit of the Hubb Community Kitchen has always been one of caring, giving back and helping those in need, initially in Grenfell and now throughout the UK.&nbspA home-cooked meal from one neighbour to another, when they need it most, is what community is all about.”How to support our campaign“I’m so proud of the women of the Hubb Community Kitchen, and the continued support The Felix Project gives them to carry out these acts of goodwill, which at this moment are urgently needed.&nbspI’m equally moved by the many people who are contributing to campaign to raise money for these vital organisations in the wake of Covid-19.”The meals will be prepared in the cooks’ homes and delivered by another charity, StreetGames, which runs the Fit And Fed campaign that aims to provide nutritious meals for children at risk of going hungry during the school holidays.The Duke of Sussex, who saw the charity’s work during a visit to one of its centres in Streatham last year, put it in touch with the kitchen.Harry and Meghan on Thursday&nbspcompleted two days of volunteering with Project Angel Food in California, helping to deliver food parcels to people in need.The Hubb Community Kitchen was set up in the aftermath of the Grenfell Tower disaster in June 2017, when a group of local women gathered in a communal kitchen at the Al-Manaar Muslim Cultural Heritage Centre.The duchess first visited it in January 2018 and has continued to make regular private visits. She wrote the foreword for Together, a collection of the women’s own personal recipes from across Europe, the Middle East, North Africa and the eastern Mediterranean.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Mark Curtin, Felix’s chief executive, said: “The women of Hubb Community Kitchen have stepped up yet again in the face of a global pandemic.“We stand together with all of our partners to get food to people most at risk of experiencing hunger and malnutrition in this time of need.”Evgeny Lebedev, a shareholder in&nbspThe Independent, said: “It is a pleasure to have the backing of the Duchess of Sussex for our campaign.&nbspHer support for the survivors of the Grenfell fire is truly admirable. Our campaign will continue to support the Hubb Community Kitchen, along with so many other essential community organisations at this time. This is a crisis, and I am grateful for Meghan’s endorsement.”The Independent is encouraging readers to help groups that are trying to feed the hungry across the country – find out how you can help by clicking here. title: coronavirus council funding england rough sleepers
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘Up and down the country&nbspcouncil&nbspworkers are the unsung heroes as we tackle this virus,’ says ministerCouncils across England will be given be given an additional £1.6bn in funding to deal with the coronavirus crisis, Local Government Secretary Robert Jenrick has announced,&nbspafter a warning many faced financial failure if they had to shoulder the burden.The cash injection doubles the funding available to councils in England to deal with the effects of the crisis, after&nbsp£1.6bn was announced earlier this year.&nbspThe extra cash will help councils&nbspdeal with the immediate impact of the pandemic, including helping rough sleepers off the streets and schemes to assist extremely vulnerable people shielded in their own homes.The Local Government Information Unit think tank has warned that councils will “fail in large numbers” unless ministers made good on his earlier promise to “do whatever is necessary” to support them.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAs he sought to head off a damaging row with local authorities, Mr Jenrick praised them as&nbsp“unsung heroes” in the fight against Covid-19.Announcing the extra money, Mr Jenrick said it would help protect vital services.“We stand shoulder to shoulder with local government and my priority is to make sure they are supported so they can continue to support their communities through this challenging time,” he said.“Up and down the country council workers are the unsung heroes as we tackle this virus. They are in the front line of the national effort to keep the public safe and deliver the services people need. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.UK has 'never seen an economic crisis like this one' says chancellorMore than 140,000 firms have applied for government help for 1 million&nbspfurloughed staff within hours of the scheme going live, Rishi Sunak has said.The chancellor said businesses will receive cash&nbspwithin six days from the coronavirus job retention scheme, which allows firms to put staff on a leave of absence - known as a furlough - with the government paying up to 80 per cent of their wages.Employers claimed for 67,000 jobs in the first 30 minutes of the scheme opening, according to HM Revenue &amp Customs (HMRC).Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Sunak announced the plans last month as part of a mammoth effort by the government to prop up the economy during the coronavirus outbreak.He told the daily Downing Street press briefing: As of 4pm this afternoon, over 140,000 firms have applied and the grants they'll receive will help pay the wages of more than a million people.A million people who if they hadn't been furloughed would have been at risk of losing their job.The UK has never seen an economic crisis like this one, Mr Sunak said, adding that the&nbspgovernment has had to put aside ideology and orthodoxy to save the economy.He said the goal of the new schemes was to maintain our economy's productive capacity so that we can bridge through this crisis.Mr Sunak refused to be drawn on the cost of the furlough scheme or whether it would be extended, saying:&nbspWe don't have an estimate of take up yet - it's just the first day the scheme is open and I expect those numbers to continue to increase over the coming days.Businesses have until Wednesday to apply for the scheme to meet payroll deadlines, with Mr Sunak revealing payments will be made within six working days from applications being received.Torsten Bell, chief executive&nbspof the Resolution Foundation thinktank, said the first tranche of claims would cost an estimated&nbsp£4.2bn over 3 months.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: endure only once lockdown lift timing right
story: IT is vital we endure this lockdown nightmare only once.It is gruelling for us all, is costing £billion a day and wrecking the economy. But it would be an even greater catastrophe to relax it early, suffer a second wave of infections and have to do it all again.Aside from the new toll of lost lives, many businesses which limp through one shutdown will not survive a second.So Dominic Raab’s decision to extend our virtual house arrest for three weeks seems fair while it remains unclear how successfully we are battling Covid-.He, and preferably a fit-again Boris Johnson, must time this exactly right. As the Foreign Secretary said, we are at a “delicate and dangerous stage”. But it is vital to review it every day.If the statistics show clearer progress in, say, another week, the Government must prioritise setting a date for partially reopening schools and some firms.We need light at the end of the tunnel.YET more depressing evidence of the inept complacency of Public Health England.“It is very unlikely anyone receiving care in a care home will become infected,” it glibly declared in February.Why  It was clear the virus posed its greatest threat to old folk. A care home was the perfect place for it to flourish.We have seen heroic NHS efforts to save lives and expand capacity, not least in the new Nightingale hospitals built with Army help. Britain showed our appreciation again last night at pm.But PHE’s record is woeful. For years it fixated on cutting our sugary treats, only to be blindsided by its first REAL crisis in decades. Even now it seems to be the major roadblock on testing.Its experts boasted of their “belt and braces” approach to protecting us all from Covid- . . .Only to be caught with their pants down.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealIT is sickening that a grasping phone firm will profit from your final farewell call to a relative dying from coronavirus in hospital.Hospedia, which also charges patients £ a day to watch TV, won’t drop their p-a-minute fee to ring a bedside phone even after mobile firms scrapped theirs.It should NEVER be possible to fleece patients or relatives, let alone during this terrible global crisis.Have a heart, Hospedia. Axe this today.TOM Moore must have thought he’d done his bit for Britain  years ago, fighting in Burma. Fate had further plans for him.Not only has Captain Tom raised £million for NHS staff, he has united the nation during this new “war”.He already has medals on his chest.Let’s see one Moore.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: figures show lockdown is starting work
story: THE future of this country depends on decisions made by ministers in the weeks and months ahead.If they relax restrictions too soon, thousands more Brits will lose loved ones before their time.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Butlockdown goes on for too long, the creaking economy will finally croak — leaving millions destitute.Which is why now is the wrong moment for aggressive finger-pointing.Yes, Britain’s initial reaction to the outbreak was far from perfect. Public Health England was embarrassingly underprepared, and it’s quite possible that ministers or their scientic advisers were too blase.But we are where we are. And brave, wise, le-saving decisions are made by confident politicians at the very top of their game — not terried men and women looking over their shoulders and worrying how they’ll be judged at a massively expensive public inquiry.The Government’s lockdown strategy is backed by an overwhelming majority of the public. And the figures show that it’s starting to work. Let’s cut the backseat driving and let Boris and his team get on with it.THE PPE crisis unfolding in hospitals and care homes shames this nation.Britain has the raw materials to kit out staff. Sothe Government and private companies worked effectively together, we have no doubt that our NHS heroes could get the protection they need.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThere has been little explanation of why deals between firms and the Government haven’t been made quickly and effectively.It leaves Britain at the mercy of foreign countries. And the consequences are deadly.When a bunch of box packers at an airport in Turkey make a mistake, our frontline staff are left high and dry.We’ve never been fans of pointless bureaucracy. And when our doctors, nurses and carers are at risk, something has to give. Fast.WE couldn’t be more proud of the great British public.For four weeks, we’ve been cooped up indoors while the sunshine blazes through the window. But — with the exception of a few covidiots — we’ve resisted temptation and stuck to the rules.And our tremendous efforts weren’t in vain. According to one top scientist, Britain is over the first peak.That doesn’t mean we’re out of the woods yet. If we gave up now, we’d face a second wave and another crippling lockdown which thousands of British companies simply couldn’t survive.Butwe hold tight, there really is light at the end of the tunnel.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking readers to sign the petition online at thesun georgecrossfornhs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trevor kavanagh public health england
story: WE are all pulling together following the rules, helping our neighbours, applauding the NHS – a genuinely United Kingdom.But the blame game is already in full swing.Labour’s vow to avoid playing party politics with a global emergency has bitten the dust, with Boris Johnson effectively accused of leaving voters to die.But it’s the Opposition’s job to oppose and politicians are paid to take the flak.Broadcasters and newspapers, including our Sunday Times stablemate, are piling in with suggestions Boris has been fiddling while Rome burned.They claim the PM was skiving on five-day weeks while spending weekends at Chevening, a “grace-and- favour country retreat” in Kent, instead of tackling the incoming apocalypse.As the earliest reports of the disease were reaching the West, the idle blighter was “sunning himself” on the luxury island of Mustique with pregnant fiancée Carrie Symonds.This, remember, was after the longest war of political attrition ever seen in a hostile House of Commons and an exhausting General Election where Boris scored a landslide victory.Nobody in Europe or America was raising the Covid- alarm at this time.As French President Emanuel Macron admitted last week, the entire Western world was caught on the hop. His government has “made mistakes” — and so has ours.But presidents and prime ministers have a lot on their plates. When it comes to health alarms, they rely on experts.It would take a very brave prime minister indeed to ignore the people appointed to safeguard the nation’s health when lives are at risk.And the advice from those experts — the sprawling Public Health England in particular — was that Britain faced no more than a larger-than-usual dose of winter flu.PHE was against German-style mass testing and, when caught flat-footed, rejected help from commercial laboratories in providing those tests.PHE failed to build stocks of personal protective equipment — including masks, gowns and gloves — despite a  test run showing these were a priority.PHE dragged its feet over sourcing ventilators for intensive-care patients and extra hospital beds.Frequently when running short of crucial gear, PHE resisted offers of outside help, leaving the NHS scrambling to catch up.And when it came to opening London’s ,-bed Nightingale emergency hospital, it was the Army that did the job in nine days.It was also PHE who insisted the British public would be protected by “herd immunity”.The sooner  per cent of the population had contracted the virus and become immune, the better, it said.Boris faithfully followed their lead until another expert, Prof Neil Ferguson, issued a nightmare prediction of , dead unless Britain was locked up overnight.It was Ferguson who in the Blair years forecast mass burials on the scale of the Great Plague during the “Mad Cow” scare and the foot-and-mouth outbreak.Neither Armageddon scenario came remotely close.Once this is over and the inevitable inquiry is held, Boris and his government will inevitably be in the dock.So will PHE, a fiercely territorial quango with a giant £.billion budget.Much of this goes on pay and perks for well-cushioned executives, with  staff on six-figure salaries — a nanny-state rich list.Its website boasts its job is to “protect and improve the nation’s health and wellbeing”.And yet this box-ticking bureaucracy — obsessed with sugary drinks and ersity — has failed at the first hurdle.It shares with the higher reaches of the NHS a suspicion of fleet-footed commercial rivals and deep-seated hostility to the “profit motive”.Criticism, still muted, is widespread within the medical community, including frontline doctors and consultants.Every Thursday at pm, a grateful nation stands and applauds NHS staff working around the clock to save lives at the risk of their own.The same cannot be said for the inflexible, politically correct quango that binds the hands of medical staff in the name of an outdated socialist credo on health provision: State good, private bad.Much will need to change after Covid-. And that change must start with Public Health England.MINISTERS are looking at a traffic-light system to lt lockdown. Red for Stop, green for Go, with amber in between.Overzealous cops and councils are being reined in. ­Common sense is taking over. Families can now attend funerals.We might be able to say goodbye to dying ­relatives. Parks will reopen to the ­public. Benches have been deemed safe to sit on.So how about allowing non-contact sporting activities that boost both physical and mental health Swimming pools are surely safe. So are tennis, badminton and golfplayers are sensible and wear gloves.Even gyms could reopensocial distancing is observed.Let’s start getting our lives back.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit redundancy pay benefits
story: MORE than a million Brits have turned to Universal Credit to prop them up during the coronavirus crisis, we take you through what will affect Universal Credit payments.How much you earn - including payments your previous employer might have paid you when you left your job - will affect how much you can be given.The Government has announced the Universal Credit standard allowance will be raised by £, a year for the next  months due to the coronavirus outbreak.Brits who are self-employed and struggling thanks to the impact of the virus can also apply for the six-in one benefits scheme.The minimum standard allowance for Universal Credit dfers depending on your circumstances - such as whether youre in a couple, or have children.How much your allowance is depends on a range of factors including your income, and total assets - both of which can be changed by payments from previous employers such as holiday pay or last pay cheques.Any income or earnings will affect how much Universal Credit you will be entitled to.This is what is known as the taper rate - where p is deducted from your benefit payment for every £ you earn over a certain amount.Most people have a certain amount they can work every month without getting cash taken off from their benefits.If youre not receiving help for housing that allowance is £ a month.If you do get housing help, the allowance is lower - £.UC will take into account what comes in every month, and will adjust your payment according to what you get paid.Your income can be anything from earnings for paid work - this will include any holiday pay paid out by employers after you leave.Soyou have a large last pay cheque, you might not be entitled to anything for the first month youre out of work.Last pay cheques paid to you instead of your notice period will also be counted as income when calculating your Universal Credit payments.If your employer pays you back for expenses made while you were working there, that will affect your allowance.And bonuses will count too. Many people are complaining that they are having to wait in queues of up to , people just to get on to the website.But DWP has revealed when its website is quietest to help those applying or checking for updates.To make an account, youll need an email address and a phone number.After that, youll need to answer a set of questions about your current circumstances, known as your to do list.These include things like when you last received payment for a job, what your household income is and how many people depend on you financially.If youve lost your job, Citizens Advice recommends that you dont apply until youve received your final wages or any final holiday pay.This is because any money you receive after youve applied for Universal Credit will count as income and mean that youre entitled to less in your first payment.You will then need to confirm your identity online.In certain circumstances, youll be able to apply over the phone, such as those who dont have regular access to the internet, are visually impaired, or have a physical condition that stops you from using a computer or smartphone.To do this, you will need to contact the Universal Credit helpline to askyou can apply by phone or arrange a home visit.In this case, someone can call them on your behalfyou cant do it yourself.If your capital - or total assets - including stocks and savings, is over £, your UC allowance will be reduced.For every £, or any part of £, you have over £, your Universal Credit will reduce by £. in the assessment period.Soyou have savings of £, - your allowance will be reduced by £..If you are married or live with your partner, you have to apply together, and their capital will also be counted.If you have more than £, in savings, you wont be eligible for Universal Credit.Redundancy payouts are not treated as income and therefore are not subject to the taper rate.But they are counted in your total assets - sothey take you over the £, mark it can impact how much your monthly payment is.Any repayments of income tax or National Insurance contributions will be treated as earningsyou were still in paid work in the tax year the repayment relates to.If you werent in paid work - it will be counted in your total assets, rather than earnings, and your payment likely wont change.One million people are already receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly  million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes  weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vintage rally car driven paul walker jump scene sale
story: The  Mark I RS was used in a dramatic scene in Fast and Furious  when the late actor Paul Walker jumped it over a highway.In the scene, which sees the car being chased by a tank, it flies over four lanes of traffic before landing seamlessly and driving off at speed.In reality, the motor was left a complete wreck - and was not used again in the Canary Islands-shot film.After the movies release in , the Escort was put in storage in the UK until it was located and bought by a collector.The enthusiast spent £, replacing almost every part on the car, ing it to immaculate condition.It has a stylish blue body, white stripes and gold wheels.Inside is a stripped-back, racing interior and under the bonnet is a . litre Vauxhall engine.Since the work was completed, the RS has covered around  miles - effectively making it a brand new car.And it has now been put up for sale with The Classic and Sportscar Centre of West Knapton, North Yorks.The dealers say they have experienced a huge amount of interest with more than , people viewing their online advert in a week.James Szkicer, from the centre, said: This is pretty much a brand new car and weve had about , views on the advert already which is a hell of a lot.There is a good market for Fast Fords at the moment and I would also expect this to appeal to film collectors and fans of the movies.It runs absolutely brilliantly and only has just a few miles on the clock.Anyone interested in purchasing the Escort should contact The Classic and Sportscar Centre.

title: 14000 apply for furlough scheme
story: MORE than , firms have applied for the Governments furlough scheme on the first day - and it will pay the wages of one million people in days.The Chancellor said that since the scheme opened up at am this morning, it had been inundated with requests for state grants.The scheme allows employers to claim up to  per cent of a furloughed employee’s wages, capped at £, a month.In all, , HMRC staff will man phones and webchat services to answer questions so money is available as soon as possible.And it will pay them within six days, he said today, just in time for the April payday.It comes as:We’ve never seen an economic crisis like this, the Chancellor told the nation this evening in the No press conference.Times like this demand that we put aside ideology and orthodoxy… times like this demand that the state turns to its immediate purpose - its protection and support of people.We promised the support would be available by the end of April.Today we deliver our promise.He said that , firms had applied for help in just ten hours today.That will pay the wages of at least one million people - who may have lose their jobs otherwise.That is a leline for families all over Britain. But we would say this to the Chancellor: Be straight with the public over what all this will cost.Too many think the Government can fund this bailout until the virus burns itself out or a vaccine arrives. It cannot.And every penny will have to be paid back, over decades, by taxpayers.Mr Sunak has warned of hardship ahead. Too few grasp just how hard it will be.Economists predicted that todays help will cost around £.billion for three months of help.Dan Tomlinson from the Resolution Foundation, said: The sheer scale of applications for the Government’s Job Retention Scheme on its opening day shows just how badly the scheme is needed.Without firms having the option to furlough staff, Britain could be facing the prospect of totally unprecedented numbers of people being unemployed.The claims made today alone are set to cost at least £. billionstaff are furloughed for three months.Its up to your place of work to apply to the scheme, meaning you wont need to contact the government yourself.To access the scheme, your employer must comply with the following:To be furloughed, you must have been on a payroll on March .Although furlough leave can be backdated to March , the portal your employer will use to register your furloughed status only launched today.Consequently, you will not be paid until the end of this month.Workers can ask previous employers to rehire and furlough them, eventhey left for another job, but firms dont have to do this.Meanwhile, the Chancellor also confirmed tonight that , gowns have arrived from Myanmar as ministers desperately try to stop needed PPE from running out.Mr Sunak said: “This is an international challenge that many other countries are experiencing.“Alongside the efforts of British businesses, and our embassies around the world, we are working hard to get the PPE our frontline NHS and social care staff need.”He insisted there were regular shipments despite the “unexpected delays” to a consignment of PPE due to arrive today from Turkey.“Today we unloaded a shipment of , gowns from Myanmar,” he said.“We are, of course, continuing to pursue every possible option for PPE procurement.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with shock figure means nearly a third of Britain’s workers have been hit.After pressure from The Sun, he has opened the Job Retention Scheme that lets firms claim cash from the Government ten days earlier than planned.Last week he announced he would extend the scheme until the end of June too, to give help for longer.He will also make sure that no one can be made redundant until the programme ends.The Resolution Foundation think tank calculates eight million will go on to the scheme, but million will lose their jobs.She added: I think it’ll be very interesting to see in the future, when all the science is done, what relationship there is between the viruses that have circulated.Spain is one of the worst affected countries in Europe, and some parts of Liverpool have some of the the worst rates of coronavirus outside London and the West Midlands.Just eleven days after the match on March  at Anfield, Boris Johnson locked down Britain and ordered everyone to stay indoors.Critics have said the match should never have taken place, as it may have helped spread the disease in and around the country.Yesterday the Madrid Mayor admitted it was a mistake for it to go ahead, but ministers tonight insisted they made the right calls at the right time.Other games around the time had been cancelled, but , fans still flew over from Spain to see it.Travel from the UK to Spain was restricted the day after the match. Mr Sunak has also unveiled a £.billion package for start-up firms not eligible for emergency business cash.The Chancellor also revealed that , loans have been accepted to businesses to help them keep going throughout the country - double the number of the week before.He said that some operational tweaks he had made would help, and he was watching very carefully to make sure the cash goes to where it is needed.Yesterday The Sun reported that at least , firms are still waiting for a cash leline.The British Business Bank, set up specically to help small firms, has title: girl spat on coronavirus barnsley
story: A VILE yob spat on a three-year-old girls face while claiming he had coronavirus in a sickening attack.Matt Batty, , was walking with daughter Alice-Rose when they were targeted by the gang of four thugs near their home in Barnsley.The youngster had told them they needed to go home because of the nasty bugs when one spat on his hand and wiped it down her face.They even tried stealing Matts shopping bag containing milk and sugar before fleeing on their bikes following the horror on Sunday.The dad-of-two told Examiner Live: We were walking back from the shops and my daughter saw these lads on their bikes and she said to me can I go out on my bike I said she couldnt because of the nasty bugs as thats how weve been explaining it to her and I said they shouldnt be out on their bikes.My daughters a social butterfly so she said to them you need to go home boys because of the nasty bugs.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThey all then sped round and started hurling abuse at us and I told them to calm it down because shes three years old - just leave it be.We carried on walking past these bollards and I heard them behind on their bikes. I heard this spitting noise and I thought are you joking me I felt something hit my back and then I saw one of them spit in his hand and wipe it down the side of my daughters face and say Ive got corona.Little Alice-Rose broke down when she ed home and is now terried to play outside in case the nasty boys attack her again.Matt and we Katie have since phoned the police, who visited their home to reassure the youngster.Alice-Rose even gted the officer one of her Easter eggs as a thank you present but her parents are still fuming over the vile assault.Matt said: Its not a joke or a laughing matter. People are dying from this and its not funny.They need to grow up. How would they like itone of us did it to them  How would they like itI spat on my hand and hurled abuse at a three-year-old Its not like she was aggressive and they should have just laughed it off. If this boy is willing to spit on his hand and wiped it down my daughters face, what would happenhe did it to a pensioner or someone more vulnerable who couldnt defend themselves South Yorkshire Police confirmed they were investigating and are appealing for anyone with information to come forward.A spokesperson said: If you have any information which could help please call  quoting incident number  of April .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast temperature hot april
story: Despite the country remaining under strict coronavirus lockdown measures, experts predict scorching temperatures will hit C across the UK this week. With the nation still encouraged to stay at home to maintain social distancing, experts believe this months overall average will beat the  best of .C- becoming the warmest April in England since records began in .It follows Easter Bank Holidays record-breaking temperatures of C - thought to be Britains hottest Easter weekend for  years.Met Office forecaster Bonnie Diamond said: “It’s going to be a week of wall to wall sunshine for much of the country, very little rainfall.Temperatures are warming up day on day.Thursday we could see highs of low C and reaching C on Thursday and possibly Friday.“I wouldn’t rule out the likes of Greater London areas and southern regions even reaching C.”Asked whether this week could see the hottest day of the year, she said: “Although C might be a bit of a push - it’s not impossible with light winds and sun-traps.“Likely Friday is going to be a similarly warm day but as we head towards the weekend, we are likely to lose the southwesterly wind and ato less warm temperatures.The scorching temperatures are set to continue well into April according to expert predictions.The Met Office’s long-range forecast from Friday to Sunday  May reads: “It is expected to be largely fine and dry with plenty of sunshine to start this period, with any risk of showery conditions confined to the south of England.“When, at times, unsettled conditions reach the south, it may also carry a risk of thunder and lightning.“Temperatures are expected to be rather warm for most, but perhaps cool along eastern coastline.”

title: oil prices wti crude futures negative coronavirus
story: The price of a barrel of crude oil slumped to less than - making it cheaper than a packet of sweets.Oil producers are now paying buyers to take it off their hands over fears storage capacity could run out in May.Due to quarantine orders in almost every state, demand for oil had dried up as Americans are no longer using their cars.The death toll in the US has soared above ,.Oil firms are now renting tankers to store the surplus supply - which is what has driven the price of US oil in the negative.The price of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate, which is the benchmark for US oil, started trading at a negative price today for first time in history, falling as low as .a barrel.The devastating drop today was partly driven by a technicality of the global oil market.Oil is traded on its future price and the contracts for May are due to expire tomorrow. Traders wanted to offload those holding so they wouldnt accumulate storage costs by having to take in the delivery.This is a rapid descent from the a barrel that oil was priced at a few months ago.June future prices for WTI were also down today, but trading at above per barrel.The US collapse will be a blow to US President Donald Trump, who has gone to great s to protect the oil sector, including backing moves by Opec and Russia to cut production and pledging support for the industry.Meanwhile, Brent Crude, which is the European benchmark, was also down to less than a barrel.Global oil prices have fallen as coronavirus continues to rampage across the world - with many countries under lockdown and restrictions of movement measures.More than .million people have been infected globally and the current death toll is about ,.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits coronavirus restrictions throughout 2020
story: BRITAIN will have to live with many of the coronavirus restrictions throughout  as ministers adopt a “suck it and see” strategy to slowly see what works.Instead of any clean end to lockdown, senior government figures tonight braced the nation to expect a very long path out of it through the summer and deep into the autumn.It emerged this evening that Downing Street has even banned the term ‘exit’ from its own lockdown planning.No officials now refer to what happens after the current three week extension that ends on May  as “next phase”.A “suck it and see” plan is now being drawn up based on scientists’ data crunching to see what restrictions to try easing first.One senior figure told The Sun: “We will try a bit at a time, and then pause, so we can see what effect that has on the transmission rate. The pace will be very gradual.While a few restrictions may be eased next month, such as allowing some smaller shops to reopen, the PM’s official spokesman yesterday confirmed there will be no “wholesale” lting of them.There are also plans being drawn up to toughen them in areas where the virus’s spread is still alarmingly high - with concerns over a lack of face masks and PPE for NHS workers.One Whitehall source said yesterday there are “three dferent epidemics right now”, where the virus is spreading at dferent rates – slower in the wider community, but faster in care homes and in hospitals.Two scenarios thought likely by insiders now are schools only ing at the earliest after the half-term break on June .But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThe other is many people being asked to still work from home into the summer too so crowded public transport can still be avoided.The latest government thinking comes despite the spiralling damage lockdown is doing to the economy.After it emerged recuperating Boris Johnson himself has deep fears about ending the lockdown prematurely, the PM’s official spokesman said: “The big concern is a second peak. That is ultimately what will do most damage to health and the economy.“If you move too quickly, the virus will start to spread exponentially again.“Lting social distancing measures wholesale, could lead to the virus spreading exponentially again.”The quad of senior ministers in charge of the coronavirus fight in the PM’s absence have tasked the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesto try to work out how the Covid- transmission rate is affected by the easing of dferent measures.SAGE meets again today, chaired by Chief Scientic Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance, but it is expected to be title: coronavirus pandemic freedom britain orwell
story: IMAGINE a Britain where everyone dutully carries an identity card and the Government tracks the movements of all its terried citizens.It is a bleak world of curfews and crackdowns, of mass surveillance and monitoring systems - with facial recognition cameras looming over every street corner.In public spaces, loudspeakers blare out official safety messages. On each phone there is an app that reports back to the authorities on the users’ health and online activities.Nor is there any escape in the home. The very concept of privacy barely exists when the state can use sophisticated technology to keep watch on our behaviour.This vision sounds like a nightmare, but it could become all too real thanks to the coronavirus.In its fallout, Covid- may end up causing as much damage to our essential freedoms as to our health - with the new menace of Big Brother on its way.Already the current emergency has led to the first comprehensive lockdown in British history.Evenit has been necessary to slow the spread of the virus, it is nevertheless a draconian measure that would have been unthinkable only a few weeks ago.Effectively the entire public has been placed under house arrest.Normal le has been brought juddering to a halt, while the police have been given unprecedented powers to enforce the quarantine.Even sitting for too long on a park bench or taking a leisurely drive have become offences against the state.With heroic stoicism, the vast majority of people have accepted this policy, seeing it as the only realistic means to protect the NHS and lessen the transmission of coronavirus.They hope that once the worst of the crisis has passed, there will be ato the Britain that they love, where inidual rights are respected and the power of the state is limited.Above all, this is my deepest wish too - though the chances look slim.One of the reasons why I, as an Irishman, admire this country so much is because of the British tradition of liberty, reflected in Magna Carta, parliamentary democracy and the defeat of Nazi tyranny.Unfortunately, even when the current lockdown is lted, it is possible that heavy-handed control by the state will remain.Quarantine may be temporary, but authoritarianism could be permanent.This is because officialdom, shaken by the unexpected scale of the coronavirus crisis, will be determined to prevent its resurgence by any means necessary.That will involve far more than just the maintenance of social distancing and the wearing of face masks.An arsenal of other measures could be deployed in the fight.One will be the reintroduction of curfews at the first sign of any new flare up in cases.If there is such a setback, the mood of the authorities will be even more intolerant towards any breaches. Fines will be heavier, jail terms longer.The skies will be filled with the sound of helicopters and the sight of drones as police — or even the Army — embark on ruthless enforcement.Another change is likely to be the advent of biometric identity cards, backed up by a comprehensive database of the entire population.Such a system has long been the dream of bureaucrats in Whitehall, and the aftermath of the crisis provides the perfect excuse for its imposition.Its appeal is all the greater because the latest type of cards operate with biotechnology that scans eyes and fingerprints.Only last year, the European Union passed a regulation requiring all national identity card systems on the continent to comply with new biometric standards.The British state will not stop there in its new crusade.In the name of health protection, mobile phone companies could be required to share data on their clients.According to the New Statesman, British Telecom, which owns the EE network, is already “in talks with the Government about handing over phone location and usage data” for the purpose of monitoring adherence to the lockdown.Similarly, tracking apps on devices could also be made obligatory so that the Government will be able to trace the contacts of anyone infected and ensure compliance with quarantine rules.Just as some criminals on release have to wear electronic tags, anyone who has tested positive for the virus may be ordered to wear a medical wristband even when self-isolation is over.Alternatively, those who test negative could be given immunity certicates.These initiatives will be accompanied by a political drive to reinforce support for the state, as happens in wartime.In a distinctly un-British way, people will be encouraged to snitch on those who fail to abide by the rules.Challenges to ruling orthodoxy will be seen as a form of subversion.If that sounds far-fetched, consider how laws to tackle discrimination or terrorism are now used to uphold fashionable ideology, as highlighted in the outrageous recent case where Lincolnshire businessman Harry Miller was questioned by police for allegedly sending a “transphobic” tweet.In the new Britain scarred by corona, the whole relationship between the state and the public will be inverted.The Government is meant to be accountable to the people.But, burdened with ID cards, curfews and tracking apps, the people will be accountable to the Government.There is an echo here of the George Orwell’s novel , which painted a terrying picture of Britain under totalitarian rule.In Orwell’s society gripped by permanent crisis, the citizenry were monitored day and night by the state.The propaganda and all-seeing eye of Big Brother could never be avoided, “always watching and the voice enveloping you, asleep or awake, indoors or outdoors, in the bath or in bed.In the present global crisis, many look to the experience of Asia, which has had far lower Covid death rates than the West.But that is a dangerous stance. First it ignores the fundamental point that China is responsible for the spread of this disease through its cover-up, persecution and lies.The country should be in the dock, not garnered with praise.Second it glosses over the oppressive nature of many of these Asian regimes, particularly that run by the tyrannical Chinese communist party.China has eagerly embraced new technology, like tracking devices, facial recognition cameras, eye-scanning security barriers and online data gathering, precisely because they drastically enhance the power of the state machine.Indeed, the country likes to boast that it is building the “world’s largest camera surveillance network”.As an example, in Guangzhou province, the commercial hub of southern China, tablets have been recently installed on buses to promote safety.Passengers are expected to lean their foreheads close to the tablet so that their photos and temperatures can be taken.China is also establishing a sinister “social credit system”, where behaviour is monitored to assess a citizen’s trustworthiness.Those given high ratings by the state can receive rewards like employment offers, shorter waiting times in hospitals and discounts at hotels.It is a recipe for bureaucratic despotism and political infantilisation.Other Asian nations, while nothing like as cruel as China, are also using technology as a tool to corral their public.Hong Kong has introduced mandatory wristbands for those in quarantine so they can be tracked.Taiwan has a monitoring system known as “the electronic fence” where those who are meant to be in isolation will be visited by the authoritiesthey turn off their mobiles.In South Korea, the government gathers huge amounts of data from phone records, CCTV images, and credit cards to help track citizens during the Covid crisis, while in Singapore, phone users are encouraged to download the “TraceTogether” app.This keeps a record of all the other numbers that have been in close proximity to the smartphone, making it easier to trace anyone who might have been near the owner in the event of a positive Covid-test.Not all of these developments are bad, provided they are genuinely used as weapons against disease rather than vehicles for the expansion of state power.But we have seen since   how the excuse of security can be used as a cover for bullying by the authorities, with the result that international air travel is often a miserable experience.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.”SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.We should not allow the same to happen on a national scale in the wake of the pandemic.As the great author C.S.Lewis wrote: “Of all tyrannies, a tyranny exercised for the good of its victims may be the most oppressive.It would be better to live under robber barons than omnipotent moral busybodies.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry meghan charles newspaper boycott
story: The couples dynamite plan to stop dealing with The Sun, the Daily Mail, theand the Daily Mirror is said to have stunned Buckingham Palace officials.The Duke and Duchess  of Sussex told the four Its not about shutting down public conversation or censoring accurate reporting.Media have every right to report on and indeed have an opinion on The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, good or bad.Executive Director Ian Murray said: Although the Duke and Duchess say they support a free press and all it stands for there is no escaping their actions here amount to censorship and they are setting an unfortunate example.Although the couple may no longer style themselves as working royals, they continue to be high-profile public figures and indeed have made plain their intention to continue to do so.By appearing to dictate which media they will work with and which they will ignore they, no doubt unintentionally, give succour to the rich and powerful everywhere to use their example as an excuse to attack the media when it suits them.The truth is that Harry and Meghan have enjoyed and continue to enjoy a huge amount of positive coverage for themselves and their causes, much of it carried in the very titles they are now targeting.They may have been stung by some of the coverage they have not liked, they may disagree strongly with some elements of that coverage and can of course take action to answer any criticism they consider unfair or inaccurate through several channels.But the answer should never be to attempt to shun inidual titles and their millions of readers.But it cant be based on a lie.They also want to be very clear: this is not in any way a blanket policy for all media.The letter also added the couple had watched people they know - as well as complete strangers - have their lives completely pulled apart for no good reason, other than the fact that salacious gossip boosts advertising revenue.The couple have stepped back from their royal duties and are living in Calornia.This week, they were pictured holding hands in loved-up display as they delivered food to LA locals in need during the coronavirus crisis.Meghan and Harry donned face masks as they delivered free meals in West Hollywood for charity Project Angel Food around their new city.Prior to stepping down from the royal family, Meghan and Harry launched an attack on the UKs newspapers in a dedicated media section on their new website Sussexroyal.The couple, who said they will be adopting a revised media approach from the spring, criticised Britains royal correspondents and said they would no longer participate in the royal rota system which has been used by Buckingham Palace for decades.Meghan is involved in legal action against Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Mail On Sunday and MailOnline, over an article which reproduced parts of the handwritten letter sent to Thomas Markle, , in August .Harry described the media as a powerful force in an emotional speech just a day after saying he and his we would be stepping back from royal duties.The duke has had a complicated and dficult relationship with the press through the years. His dislike of the media has seemingly intensied since the birth of his son Archie Mountbatten-Windsor last year.Harry was  when his mum, Princess Diana was killed in a crash after her car, driven at speed, was chased through the streets of Paris by the paparazzi.Soon after he began dating Meghan, Harry attacked the media over its abuse and harassment of his then girlfriend, with Kensington Palace warning on his behalf: This is not a game - it is her le.As The Duke and Duchess of Sussex now settle into the next chapter of their lives and no longer receive any publicly funded support, we are writing to set a new media relations policy, specically as it pertains to your organisation.Like you, The Duke and Duchess of Sussex believe that a free press is a cornerstone to any democracy - particularly in moments of crisis.At its best, this free press shines light on dark places, telling stories that would otherwise go untold, standing up for whats right, challenging power, and holding those who abuse the system to account.It has been said that journalisms first obligation is to the truth. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex agree wholeheartedly.It is gravely concerning that an influential slice of the media, over many years, has sought to insulate themselves from taking accountability for what they say or print - even when they know it to be distorted, , or invasive beyond reason.When power is enjoyed without responsibility, the trust we all place in this much-needed industry is degraded. There is a real human cost to this way of doing business and it affects every corner of society.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have watched people they know - as well as complete strangers - have their lives completely pulled apart for no good reason, other than the fact that salacious gossip boosts advertising revenue.With that said, please note that The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will not be engaging with your outlet.There will be no corroboration and zero engagement.This is also a policy being instated for their communications team, in order to protect that team from the side of the industry that readers never see. title: what is sage government
story: SAGE is the elite team of advisers responsible for ensuring that timely and coordinated scientic advice is given to decision makers in the cabinet during COBRA meetings.It is responsible for title: carrie symonds end wet markets coronavirus

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A -year-old man and a longtime Boris Johnson ally will be formally installed in the House of Lords today in a cut-down ceremony, despite the coronavirus crisis.The Lords s from its Easter break this afternoon - and will largely be operating ‘virtually’, with peers engaging in debates via video conferencing. But it has been decided to go ahead with the ceremony to officially introduce new peers to the upper house despite the nation being in lockdown. Baron Stephen Greenhalgh, a longtime ally of the Prime Minister who served as his deputy mayor for Policing, will take his seat today. And Lord Grimstone of Boscobel, the former chairman of Barclays Bank will join him on the red benches. Boris Johnson has already appointed Lord Grimstone as an Investment Minister, despite his not yet having taken his seat.One Peer told the Mirror: “It appears to be do as we say not as we do. You really couldnapost make this soap opera up. “The sooner we are abolished the better” It’s expected the usual ceremony, which involves dozens of peers, House officials, ermine robes and tri-corn hats may be scaled down in today’s ceremony. MPs are expected to approve plans for “virtual” sittings of the Commons later today.  Under proposals drawn up by the House authorities, MPs will be able to contribute to proceedings at Westminster - including questioning ministers - through video links. MPs will be urged to stay away from the chamberat all possible - with most taking part through online video conferencing. It is unclear how many will attend, with views ided among those who believe they have a duty to be present and others committed to staying away. Today’s vote will pave the way for the first virtual Prime Minister’s Questions to take place tomorrow.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCarrie Symonds has joined calls for a worldwide ban on the sale of wildle which may have provided the ideal situation for Covid- to jump to humans. Boris Johnsonaposs fiancee has signed a petition calling for a worldwide ban on the markets where animals caught in the wild are often sold for consumption.Writing on Twitter, Ms Symonds,who is a longtime animal rights activist and is expecting her first child early this summer, said the current coronavirus outbreak was a chance to start doing things better.The Covid- outbreak is widely thought to have originated in a wet market in the Chinese city of Wuhan, where it is believed to have made the jump from animals - possibly bats - to humans. But the term is confusing as not all wet markets are places where wildle are sold, some are just markets which sell cheap meat and produce. They get their name from the water poured on goods to keep them cool and fresh. China closed its wet markets in the wake of the virus, but they have recently reopened, but with some tighter regulations. The End the Trade petition signed by Ms Symonds calls for governments around the world to take action to permanently end the trade in wild animals for consumption. Together we are urging the worldaposs governments to recognise that this is among the most important decisions that the global community can make to prevent future pandemics and global disruption, it says. The emergence of novel pathogens from wild animals leading to another such pandemic must be prevented through the cessation of the commercial trade of terrestrial wild animals and closure of markets for consumption.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPupils set to take GCSE and A Level exams next year may have to repeat this year, a former head of Ofsted has said. Sir Michael Wilshaw told the BBC schools should be re-opened “as soon as it is safe to do so.” But he said some children will are “losing out” so much that they won’t be able to catch up. It comes after a survey revealed two thirds of children had not logged into online lessons. Askedsome children should repeat the year, he said: “Yes. …I think there is some argument for that. Obviously those who are about to sit examinations that decision has been made for them in terms of estimated grades. “But those who are preparing for examinations next year I think possibly need to repeat the year, and perhaps others as well. But that decision needs to be made by the Department [of Education].” He added: “They might have lost out so much by this that they need to repeat the whole year.” “It can be managedthere’s sufficient time to do that. But certainlyI was a parent of a child in year  or year , I’d want them to have the same opportunities as other children andthey’ve lost out then I think it’s up to schools and up to government to make sure they are given that opportunity.” Sir Michael said he could see schools opening up in June “as long as there is plenty of planning.”

story: NewsHow will coronavirus virtual parliament work - and will MPs have to wear a suit MPs will take part in Commons debates remotely via Zoom for the first time today - heres how it will work, who will be there in person, and whether the dress code still appliesShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. If it works, the House will consider extending the measures to a fully virtual Parliament as quickly as possible to include debates on motions and legislation and even a system of remote voting.” But how will the new virtual Parliament work  Here’s everything we know so far. Who will be there in person   Up to  MPs will still be able to be present in the chamber - although they are being strongly encouraged to stay away. They’ll include the speaker, ministers and whips where necessary. But it’s unclear yet whether some stubborn MPs will defy advice and insist on turning up in person. Strict social distancing arrangements will be in force with MPs required to sit two metres apart. Everyone  - up to  MPs - will take part in debates through Zoom video conferencing. They will be broadcast online and to large video screens set up around the chamber. What happens today  To approve the new hybrid arrangement, the House will need to sit physically on Tuesday to vote the plans through. Backbenchers will, as usual, be drawn at random although the Speaker will ensure opposition spokesmen and women and the relevant select committee heads are able to take part. Will they be able to vote remotely  The initial system does not cover remote voting, although officials are working on developing a secure system which would also have to be approved by the House before it could be adopted. title: coronavirus faces latest frontline workers
story: NewsFaces of latest frontline staff to lose coronavirus battle as th health worker diesAt least  health and care workers have died from Covid-, according to Nursing Notes, as tributes pour in for the heroes who put the needs of others before their ownShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsChrissie Emerson was a bubbly member of staff at Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Norfolk " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters.
